ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a working understanding of the field of Neurolinguistics--an impressive feat given the complexity of the field and the time we had. More importantly, I gained the skill to read, understand, and think critically about scientific papers and research, which will remain with me long past the locations of the various Brodmann Areas.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was extremely interactive. I loved how open the classroom was to asking questions and engaging in topics that interested all of us.

Strength: The lack of a textbook & fact that all of our readings were primary journal sources. Weakness: It occasionally felt like we were getting off topic, but by the time we made it to the final I realized we had learned an *immense* amount, even if it wasn't all originally on the syllabus.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The class is difficult and it's a lot of work, but it's definitely one of the most rewarding classes I've taken at Yale. This course definitely requires you to learn and approach the material in a way you might not be comfortable with, but that was very refreshing.

I would *absolutely* recommend this course to a student who is interested in neuroscience but from a more cognitive, rather than biological, perspective, or to anyone interested in language/linguistics--it's so important to understand the processing side of the theory.
